location: Athens. A hall in Timons house.

lines.text: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Good day, sir.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: I am glad youre well.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: I have not seen you long: how goes the world

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: It wears, sir, as it grows.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Ay, thats well known: But what particular rarity what strange, Which manifold record not matches See, Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: I know them both th others a jeweller.

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: O, tis a worthy lord.

lines.speaker: jeweller
lines.text: Nay, thats most fixd.

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were, To an untirable and continuate goodness: He passes. Jeweller:I have a jewel here O, pray, lets seet: for the Lord Timon, sir Jeweller:If he will touch the estimate: but, for that

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: [Reciting to himself]  When we for recompense have praised the vile, It stains the glory in that happy verse Which aptly sings the good.

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: Tis a good form.
Looking at the jewel

lines.speaker: jeweller
lines.text: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication To the great lord.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: A thing slippd idly from me. Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes From whence tis nourishd: the fire i the flint Shows not till it be struck our gentle flame Provokes itself and like the current flies Each bound it chafes. What have you there

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir. Lets see your piece.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Tis a good piece.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: So tis: this comes off well and excellent.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Indifferent.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Admirable: how this grace Speaks his own standing! what a mental power This eye shoots forth! how big imagination Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture One might interpret.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: It is a pretty mocking of the life. Here is a touch ist good

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: I will say of it, It tutors nature: artificial strife Lives in these touches, livelier than life.
Enter certain Senators, and pass over

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: How this lord is followd!

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: The senators of Athens: happy man!

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Look, more!

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors. I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man, Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug With amplest entertainment: my free drift Halts not particularly, but moves itself In a wide sea of wax: no levelld malice Infects one comma in the course I hold But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on, Leaving no tract behind.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: How shall I understand you

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: I will unbolt to you. You see how all conditions, how all minds, As well of glib and slippery creatures as Of grave and austere quality, tender down Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune Upon his good and gracious nature hanging Subdues and properties to his love and tendance All sorts of hearts yea, from the glassfaced flatterer To Apemantus, that few things loves better Than to abhor himself: even he drops down The knee before him, and returns in peace Most rich in Timons nod.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: I saw them speak together.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill Feignd Fortune to be throned: the base o the mount Is rankd with all deserts, all kind of natures, That labour on the bosom of this sphere To propagate their states: amongst them all, Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fixd, One do I personate of Lord Timons frame, Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her Whose present grace to present slaves and servants Translates his rivals.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Tis conceived to scope. This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks, With one man beckond from the rest below, Bowing his head against the sleepy mount To climb his happiness, would be well expressd In our condition.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Nay, sir, but hear me on. All those which were his fellows but of late, Some better than his value, on the moment Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance, Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear, Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him Drink the free air.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Ay, marry, what of these

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants Which labourd after him to the mountains top Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down, Not one accompanying his declining foot.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Tis common: A thousand moral paintings I can show That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortunes More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen The foot above the head. Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself  courteously to every suitor a Messenger from  VENTIDIUS talking with him LUCILIUS and other servants following

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Imprisond is he, say you

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt, His means most short, his creditors most strait: Your honourable letter he desires To those have shut him up which failing, Periods his comfort.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Noble Ventidius! Well I am not of that feather to shake off My friend when he must need me. I do know him A gentleman that well deserves a help: Which he shall have: Ill pay the debt, and free him.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Your lordship ever binds him.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom And being enfranchised, bid him come to me. Tis not enough to help the feeble up, But to support him after. Fare you well.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: All happiness to your honour!
Exit
Enter an old Athenian

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Freely, good father.

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: I have so: what of him

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Attends he here, or no Lucilius!

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: Here, at your lordships service.

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature, By night frequents my house. I am a man That from my first have been inclined to thrift And my estate deserves an heir more raised Than one which holds a trencher.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Well what further

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: One only daughter have I, no kin else, On whom I may confer what I have got: The maid is fair, o the youngest for a bride, And I have bred her at my dearest cost In qualities of the best. This man of thine Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord, Join with me to forbid him her resort Myself have spoke in vain.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: The man is honest.

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Therefore he will be, Timon: His honesty rewards him in itself It must not bear my daughter.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Does she love him

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: She is young and apt: Our own precedent passions do instruct us What levitys in youth.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: [To LUCILIUS]           Love you the maid

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: If in her marriage my consent be missing, I call the gods to witness, I will choose Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world, And dispossess her all.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: How shall she be endowd, if she be mated with an equal husband

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Three talents on the present in future, all.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: This gentleman of mine hath served me long: To build his fortune I will strain a little, For tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter: What you bestow, in him Ill counterpoise, And make him weigh with her.

lines.speaker: old athenian
lines.text: Most noble lord, Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: My hand to thee mine honour on my promise.

lines.speaker: lucilius
lines.text: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may The state or fortune fall into my keeping, Which is not owed to you!
Exeunt LUCILIUS and Old Athenian

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: I thank you you shall hear from me anon: Go not away. What have you there, my friend

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: A piece of painting, which I do beseech Your lordship to accept.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Painting is welcome. The painting is almost the natural man or since dishonour traffics with mans nature, He is but outside: these pencilld figures are Even such as they give out. I like your work And you shall find I like it: wait attendance Till you hear further from me.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: The gods preserve ye!

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel Hath sufferd under praise.

lines.speaker: jeweller
lines.text: What, my lord! dispraise

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: A more satiety of commendations. If I should pay you fort as tis extolld, It would unclew me quite.

lines.speaker: jeweller
lines.text: My lord, tis rated As those which sell would give: but you well know, Things of like value differing in the owners Are prized by their masters: believet, dear lord, You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Well mockd.

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: No, my good lord he speaks the common tongue, Which all men speak with him.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Look, who comes here: will you be chid Jeweller: Well bear, with your lordship.
Enter APEMANTUS

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: Hell spare none.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow When thou art Timons dog, and these knaves honest.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Why dost thou call them knaves thou knowst them not.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Are they not Athenians

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Then I repent not. Jeweller: You know me, Apemantus Thou knowst I do: I calld thee by thy name.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Whither art going

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: To knock out an honest Athenians brains.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Thats a deed thoult die for.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: The best, for the innocence.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Wrought he not well that painted it

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: He wrought better that made the painter and yet hes but a filthy piece of work.

lines.speaker: painter
lines.text: Youre a dog.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Thy mothers of my generation: whats she, if I be a dog

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: No I eat not lords.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: An thou shouldst, thou ldst anger ladies.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: O, they eat lords so they come by great bellies.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Thats a lascivious apprehension.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Not so well as plaindealing, which will not cost a man a doit.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What dost thou think tis worth

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: How now, philosopher!

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Thou liest.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Art not one

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Then I lie not.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Art not a poet

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

lines.speaker: poet
lines.text: Thats not feigned he is so.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What wouldst do then, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Een as Apemantus does now hate a lord with my heart.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What, thyself

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Ay.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Wherefore

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: That I had no angry wit to be a lord. Art not thou a merchant

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: Ay, Apemantus.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

lines.speaker: merchant
lines.text: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Traffics thy god and thy god confound thee!
Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What trumpets that

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse, All of companionship.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Pray, entertain them give them guide to us. You must needs dine with me: go not you hence Till I have thankd you: when dinners done, Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights. Most welcome, sir!
Exeunt some Attendants
Enter ALCIBIADES, with the rest

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: So, so, there! Aches contract and starve your supple joints! That there should be small love mongst these sweet knaves, And all this courtesy! The strain of mans bred out Into baboon and monkey.

lines.speaker: alcibiades
lines.text: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed Most hungerly on your sight.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Right welcome, sir! Ere we depart, well share a bounteous time In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.
Exeunt all except APEMANTUS
Enter two Lords

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: What time o day ist, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Time to be honest.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: That time serves still.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: The more accursed thou, that still omittst it.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Thou art going to Lord Timons feast

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Why, Apemantus

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give thee none.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Hang thyself!

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy requests to thy friend.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Away, unpeaceable dog, or Ill spurn thee hence!

lines.speaker: apemantus
lines.text: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o the ass.
Exit

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Hes opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in, And taste Lord Timons bounty he outgoes The very heart of kindness.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: He pours it out Plutus, the god of gold, Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays Sevenfold above itself no gift to him, But breeds the giver a return exceeding All use of quittance.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: The noblest mind he carries That ever governd man.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Ill keep you company.
Exeunt
